intro: Nepeta syriaca, commonly known as Syrian catmint, is a perennial herb native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a distinctive minty aroma. Its flowering period occurs in late spring to early summer, producing clusters of small, pale blue to violet flowers. Nepeta syriaca is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional medicine for its purported calming properties.
